div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Shortest, calmest, most beautiful sea passage to Europe. Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Sofia, Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Chios, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, Constantinople.

KHARTOUM IN 3 DAYS. Express Steamers leave Suez Docks 5 p.m. every Wedensday for Port Sudan (and Suakin) in connection with Sudan Government Railways Express Luxe service to Kharteum, arriving 8 p.m. Saturdays.

Steamers leave from Suez 5 p.m. every Monday evening for JEDDA, calling one week at Tor, El Wedj, Yambo, Jedda; and the following week at Tor, Yambo, Jedda, Port Sudan, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, ADEN.
For freight or passage apply the Co.'s agencies Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, or for passage only to THOS, COOK & SON, HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE, REISE-BUREAT or other Tourist Agenecies.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. 138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.

TUESDAY, JANUARY 28, 1908.

div.head: ELECTIONS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The recent elections for the General As- sembly and the Lgislative Council have been far more keenly watched than on any previous occasion. Jt appears that this increase in interest was due tu the various political parties, who have lately appeared in Egypt, and were eager (0 secure thé election of their own candidates. The only exception to this general interest was at Helouan where everybody forgot the date of the election and nobody conse quently voted. The recent elections have once more shown the necessity for reforming the representative machinery. Lord Cromer was of this opinion and in his last report (Egypt, N° 1, 1907’, p. 28,) he says :—

“As regards the elected members both of the Council and of the Assembly, it is obvions that, under the existing system, the question of how far they are really representative ot Egyptian public opinion depends io a great degree on the interest taken in the election of the Delegates (‘Electeurs Délégués”). Lord Dofferin’s fundamental idea was to free the fellaheen from the power of the village Sheikhs, whom he regarded as the “inveterate oppressors” of the people. ‘The community,” he wrote, should be at least given a free choice of the person with wh0m the suffrage of the hamlet is to be deposited.” The conception was statesmanlike, but its realization involved the possession by the mass of the voters of qualities to which they have not yet attained. In Egypt, village politics centre on the affairs of the village. The number of those who take an interest ia events outside this narrow circle is very limited. Asa general rule either the Omdeh of the village, or some rival who aspires to he Omdeh, is elected to act as Delegate on behalf of the community. I should add that, althongh I am far from saying that there is no further room for improvement, at the same time the village authorities are now under much more effective control than was the case in Lord Dofferin'’s time. The objections to intrusting them with the suffrages of their villages have, therefore, diminished.”

The advantages of abolishing the present system and of having direct representation are obvious. It would lead to for greater interest being taken by the pnblic in the elections, would foster a sense of responsibility as yet unknown and aid more than anything else the political education of the people. Purthermore, as far as we can see, no political or adminis- trative difficulties are likely to arise from such adepartare. (nthe contrary the change is one, which might be recommended on the ground of giving to the Egyptians a right exercised by every nation endowed with re presentative institutions.

div.head: Fire at Kafr El Ashri.
div.p: At 9.35 p. m last evening a fire was disco ered by the man on the floating fire station at a carpenter's shop in Kafr el Ashri. The brigade from Mivet ei Bassal and the fire tout were quickly in attendance, when it was found that the premises were well alight. One hydr ant and the steamer were got to work, and after an hour's hard work the fire was got under. The cause of the outbreak is unknown, and the damages have not heen estimated

div.p: We beg to drawn our readers attention to an advertisement in to day's issue of a valuable collection of old China, which has just arrived at Alexandria from the Far East. The owner, Mr. William Standley, has been collecting China for many years and is desirons of disposing of a part of his collection. He will be pleased to allow any one to inspect his collection at his residence at 55 Moharrem Bey, on the ground floor of the first house leading from the main street in Rue el Guedid, any day from noon to 5 pm.

div.head: Egypt's Food Supply
div.p: A few days ago a large consignment of Roumanian cattle arrived at Alexandria from Constanza, and after passing the usual time in quarantine they were despatched to the Cairo slaughter honses under a guard from the Department of Public Health. These ani mals, althongh they appeared to be very meagre on arriving at Alexandria, sold at a very good price at Cairo The importers of these cattle, who have the animals sent on by the AngloRoumanian Company, are not at all satisfied with the first cousignment and it the next two or three consignments are not better, they will send their own buyers from England or Egypt to select younger and better conditioned animals in Roumania. If the trade in these animals turns out satisfactory, the Company will probably charter their own steamers to bring these animals direct from Constanza to Alexandria, instead of having to wait for the regular Roumanian steamer.

div.head: THE GALE.
div.p: In consequence of the bad weather telephonic communication with Bab el Karasta, Rosetta Ciate, Ibrahimieh, and hamleh is interrupted
This morning the body of a Saidi workmen was found under the debris of the wall of the partly built: Palais Crystal, which collapsed during the storm. Our 'air Correspondent writes

"The weather babeer growing steadily worse and worse these last few days, and yesterday was the most unpleasant and inclement we ever remember in Cairo Ruin had fallen heavily during the privind clavthe streets being reduced to a most lamentable condition, and the pavement being in e ally parlous state. Various fiore quails of sleet and wind wided to the cold anamneral misery throughout the day, trees being brun over, roofs being damaged by the fierceness of the wind, while at times even the horses were scarcely able to face the fury of the elements. Many streets in the native quarters must be under water, and the misery of the inhabitants in must be pitiable.

Our Port Said Correspondent reports that Sunday was one of the worst days they have had at Port Suid during the last 20 years. The wind, which was very strong early in the morning, increased during the day, and by 6 pm u furious gale was blowing accompanied with very heavy rain The damage done during the day was great several houses in the Arab village being blown down, while trees, batti houses and sentinel bores were in many cases destroyed By pu most of the principal streets were under water Yesterday the weather was a little better but there is still a strong wind and cloudy sky
Telegraphing yesterday at 5.33 pm. our Suez correspondent says "The Egyptian State Telegraph lines lave just been restored. The canal and ETC lines are still broken."

div.head: LEGAL NOTES
div.p: CAIRO MIXED TRIBUNAL
SOCIETE EGYPTIENNE DE PUBLICITE v. CAFFARI'S CO-OPERATIVE MARKETS

This case is of interest in view of certain rumours which are being circulated as to the financial position of the defendant company. It appeared that a contract had been made between Mr. J. B. Caffari and the plaintiffs, in February 1907, by which the latter were

to receive £ 280 for advertising the pros. I pectus of the defendant company then in course of formation, and the question for decision was whether Mr. Caffari had contracted on his own behalf or as agent for the company. Me. Fatica sought to show that his clients the defendants were not liable as the company was not then in existence, and objected to the seizures of his clients' property in August last by M.M. Spezzeropoulo and Koression. The Court however found that the company was in fact 'born' before the date of the transaction, and that Mr. Caffari acted on its behalf, and condemned defendants to pay the amount claimed together with costs, and fees amounting to L.E. 4. Tne saisiearrêts of August 21, 1907, were converted into saisie-excentoires. A notable comment was evoked by or request that the hearing of one of to day's cases should be deferred. In reference to the dilatory tactics of Egyptian litigants and their legal advisers Judge Tuck observed that out of 39 cases down for hearing last Wednesday only one was pleaded, the others being renvoyés for one reason or another Counsel, he added, take longer to ex plain their reasons for delay than is occupied by the actual hearing of the cases. On counsel's origin that his case would only occupy 2 minutes, the President replied that it could not be pleaded in so short a time, and Me. Bacum (for the other side) could not resist adding "especially in the case of my learned friend" whereupon he was rebuked, amid laughter.
THE GHORBAL CASE.

On Saturday last the case brought by the Helouan Development Company Limited Against the Egyptian Land and General Trust Limited and the group, who purchased the Gborbal Estate from the latter company and sold it to the Helouan Company, was down for hearing before the Alexandria Mixed Civil Court. The hearing was adjourned until the 8th February

"The Ghorbal Estate at Alexandria was sold by the Egyptian Land and General Trust Limited a group consisting of Messrs. Rossano, Bondi, Fumaroli Riches and Co., and Kamel Bey Teymour for LE 130.000. This group paid L.E. 500.000 down and were to pay the remainder in three instalments of L E. 26,769 each on May 24th, and November 24th, 1907. and May 24th, 1908. Meanwhile the group sold the estate to the Helouan Development Company Limited, with the instalments to be paid by the Helouan Development Company to the Egyptian Land and General Trust. The Helouan Development Company paid one of the instalments last May and in November asked for time to be granted for the payment of the other instalment. The Helouan Development Company at the same time made various offers, which were not accepted. The Helouan Development Company, within one day within the year of the expiration of their contract, went to law and objected to the measurements of the land, which was the subject of the sale, demanded back the money that had been paid and asked the court to grant that the contract should be resisted.
SOCIETE DES CONCERTS

The Société des Concerts showed what they really could do on Sunday. The Dvorak New World symphony was a revelation in the hands of Mr. Marsick. The full sonority of the orchestra was revealed, every least phrase was given its full significance, every effect and every point made. It is a great symphony The strange beauty of the first movement, its theme taken up by one instrument after another, and woven into the fine many-coloured texture of the whole, the delicacy, and calm breadth of the largo, the perfect scherzo, and the finale with its superb minor phrase beating and cleav. ing its path through a mass of splendid sound,
—these in the hands of a master give a striking impression,--the strange pain of old Hangary wondering at the confusion and din of the New Continent.

The César Franck - Redemption' was impressive, it had certain fine depths, and a melodious solemnity of its own, but there was throughout the suggestion of some want of cohesion, as it were an organist following his own thoughts as they came alone, in some dark church, beautiful but chaotic. Mme Baron sang Saint-Saëns La Cloche and a Handel, not without charm and skill.

There the concert--quả concert-ended. W. were treated to a weird parody of the 'Café Egyptien, as one hears it, passing swiftly in a cab, & symphony of misdirected platitudes. A listener near me suggested it as an effort to describe a day at the home for lost dogs. It is the work of one M. Charpentier and is, I hear, played at times in France, but M. Marsick was overheard on his way out, to describe it as 'une soie' ! -I understand the reason-pot excuse :-for its appearance was the refusal of the orchestra to play any. thing else as a final piece, and the reluctance of the committee to repeat any one of the 1-infinitely preferable--items that bad figured in former concerts. Yet it seems a pity to have indulged the orchestra, and wasted M. Marsick's and our time and patience on what almost served to obliterate the impression of I the whole of the rest of the concert,

div.head: CAIRO SEASON
div.p: SAVOY HOTEL

As might have been foretold, the dance at the Savoy on Saturday night was by far the most crowded one of the present season, and as brilliant a spectacle as can be witnessed at any European capital. Every table available in the dining room and restaurant was occupied, and it was hardly possible to dance with any degree of comfort during the first half of the programme. Beautiful women and beautiful toilettes were to be seen on every side: the newcomers being so numerous that any attempt to chronicle them is impossible; and it would be far easier to mention those who were absent than those who were present.

The Princess de Teado retired from the scene at a fairly early hour, but she was present among the dinner party given by Sir Ernest Cassel which also included Baroness Schey, Count Berchem, Baron von Spiege, Mr. Webb Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Sobiff, Mr Paget, Count Leyder, Mrs. Wilfred Ashley, General Thorneyssen Pasba, Birch Pasba, Mr. Rowlatt, and Mr. Hamilton. Guests of Count Kosciebrodski we're Baroness C. and Baroness, M. d'Imboff, Baron Oppenheim, Captain and Mrs. Schreiber, Captain and Mrs Dunbar, Count and Countess Bernstorff, Countess A. de Bernstorff, Baron and Baroness de Gaiffier d'Hestroy, and Mr. de Martino.

Miss Cochrane's party included Major and Mrs. Freger, Major and Mrs. Knight, Mrs. and Miss Fitz Clarence, Colonel Aylmer, Miss Balfe, Mr. Cyye, Mr. Tollemache, and Mr. Orred. Mme Sursock bad a party of eight, Mr and Mrs. Percy one of ten, Mrs. Hunting Powell had six at her table, that of Mrs. Laffary held the same number. Mrs. Scott Dalgleish, Mrs. Ezchaley, Mr and Mrs. Converse were also among the hosts and hostesses of the evening: no less than sixty tables being occupied by the various people who were present.

As for those who attended the ball, they included all the best known residents who are usually to be found at the Savoy on dance nights, very nearly all those staying in the house and the greater proportion of those staying in Ghezireh Palace and the other well known hotels. Small wonder then that we cannot keep a record of either individuals or their garments, as they fitted by in such hopeless numbers. Of the few impressions which still remain distinct was the lovely frock worn by Miss York, a filmy grey chiffon veiling an under diess of pink, with tiny tight sleeves of steel network outlining the upper arm; and the gorgeous white cotton robe of Mme Jacques Cattaui with its clinging girdle caught high at the back with an enormous cabochon emerald. Miss Barnes Lawrence was wearing if we remember rightly & satin frock lightly draped with pink
TRAMWAY WIRE BREAKAGE

One of the overhead wires of the Cairo Tramway Company fused this morning in the Sharia el Boulac opposite the Egyptian State Telegraph office, and burning for a few moments with extraordinary brilliance, the wires parted and fell to the ground, one of them narrowly missing a passer by. A few minutes later a private carriage drove up and the horse coming into contact with the wires was killed instantly. A large crowd immediately began to collect, and it was only by the efforts of one or two men to whom the danger was apparent many of these were prevented from sharing the fate of the horse, or at the least being subjected to a nasty shock, for the solitary policeman who had arrived when the crowd began to collect evidently knew nothing at all of the disaster which would overtake any one who was unfortunate enough to touch the wire. It is only due to bim to remark, however, that as soon as the danger was pointed out to him he exerted himself in trying to keep the people clear. The other naked end of the wire was left entirely unguarded. Apparently not more than one policeman could be spared in the town. Officers made their appearance but the fact that an exposed enit of charged wire was lying on the pavement some dozen yards further up the street apparently passed unnoticed, and those who among the crowds, were ignorant of the danger, have only luck to thank that they escaped it, for not the slightest attempt was made to either warn or safeguard the public by the persons responsible for the safety. And not only were the police guilty of unpardonable negligence in the matter, but we would also like to know what excuse the tramway company can offer for having continued to allow a powerful current of electricity to run through the fallen wires for fully twenty minutes after they were advised of the accident. We trust that the affair will be enquired into by the two departments concerned. The utter incompetence of the police force to deal with this matter was a revelation indeed, or perhaps we should say that the revelation lay in the inability of the force to supply sufficient men at a critical moment for the men on the spot acted with energy, though these efforts were somewhat misapplied. The loss of the horse was of course unfortunate but the blame for this can hardly be laid at anyone's door, for it occurred within a few moments of the breaking of the wires. The absence of a sufficient force of police to keep the crowds off and the delay of the tramway company in cutting off the current are matters however which will need a deal of explaining away.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE
div.p: "I PESCATORI DI PERLE.”

Of the five operas composed by Biset during his all too short career, for he died at the early age of 37, "Les pecheurs des perles” was one of his latest efforts, and was first produced at the Paris Opera House in 1863, where it was fairly well received, although it has never been what could be considered a popular opera; this may in some degree perhaps be accounted for from the fact that there are only four principals in the cast ; these however have an abundance of opportunities throughout the opera, and the choruses are quite up to the standard of those occurring in his masterpiece, and last composition, "Carmen," which was produced some twelve years later. The plot contains nothing of extraordinary interest, being one of the familial stories of love and the natural attendant jealousy.

The scene of the opera, laid in the beautiful island of Ceylon, lends itself to gorgeous stage settings and this was folly taken advantage of in last evening's production. The costuming of the chorus, however, left very great room for improvement. Egyptian headdresses and pink tights are scarcely likely to be favoured by the dusky residents of Ceylon. The ballet costumes were exceedingly becoming, but why again the pink tights and the very, very, pale faces. These possibly small defects detracted some what from the general success of the production, more especially as the principals' make ups were very Indian indeed.

For the principals we have nothing but praise, Signorina G. Finzi Magrini gave, 29 she always does, a conscientious interpretation of her role, "Leila," on whom most of the hard work devolves, and she was very capably supported by Signor Narciso Del Ry as Nadir. Signor Oreste Benedetti appeared to great advantage as Purga, and Signor Francesco in the small role of Nurabad, made an excellent impression. The orchestra in the hands of Signor G. Zaccani w28, of course, all that could be desired.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Mirza Riza Khan and H. E. Obapnès Khan have arrived at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo

The Earl of Cromer has consented to preside | at a public meeting at Guildford on January 31, under the auspices of the West Surrey branch of the British Constitution Association, "to oppose Socialism and to maintain the Empire and Constitution"

Lord Anglesey, who left Cairo just after Xmas, has returned home to Plas Newydd where he is entertaining guests for shooting, his mother Lady Alexander Paget acting as hostess. Plas-Newydd has been completely refurnished and redecorated of late. The drive up to the house is lined with magnificent rhodedendrums, and inside the park gates is the obelisk set np to mark the place of burial of the leg of the celebrated Marquis of Anglesey, who was at Waterloo.

Mr. Heaton-Armstrong M.P. and Mr. Man ville entertained a large party at the Savoy Hotel on Sunday evening the guests being : Fakhry Pasba, General Bullock,Capt the Hon. W. Trefuses, Johnson Pasha, Mr. J.R. Gibson, Mr W. W. Carey, Mr. A. P. Mack, Mr. H.G. Montgomery, Capt. RL Dawson, Maitre Carton de Wiart, Lieut. Prazer. Mr. J. A. Gunn, Mr. Hooker, Mr. Lyon, Mr. S.R. Cook son, Mr. W.C. Hornblower, Mr. W.C. Scales, Mr. P. Barnard.

('LAYTON DISINFECTION STEAMERS

The Clayton Gas Co. of Egypt, commenced active operations in Alexandria Harbour, under orders from the Quarantine Board, on Priday 17th inst. The first steamer treated by their system of disinfection and deratisation was the "Reine Marie." The Company's launch,

Clayton No. 1," which has been specially designed and built for the work, steamed op, and was quickly moored in a convenient position alongside, the flexible steel tubes connected with the disinfecting apparatus were swiftly taken over the side of the "Reine Marie," and inserted in the bold, the apparatus was then started, and worked admirably The other bold was subsequently treated in a similar manner, the entire process only occupying a few hours. We understand the results were highly satisfactory, & large numbers of dead rats and other verinin being disclosed to view when the holds were re-opened. Several of the principal Quarantine Authorities were present, and took a keen interest in the proceedings.
The company has since treated the Khedivial Mail steamers "Osmanieb" and "Saidieh," with equally gratifying results, and are to continue their operations where required.

The Clayton system is a great improvement on the hitherto existing methods, owing to its simplicity, effectiveness and economy, and we trust it may prove the means of reducing infection and quarantine restrictions to a mini. mum. At the same time it gives us residents in Egypt increased confidence in oor Quarantine Board to find they are not slow in giving a fair and impartial trial to any measures they may deem likely to increase the safety and welfare of the community

div.head: AUSTRIA'S FOREIGNRELATIONS.
div.p: Baron von Aehrenthal in his annual state. went to the Foreign Committee of the Hungarian Delegation said be rejoiced to see the Anglo German rapprochement. He was gratified that his efforts to secure friendlier re. lations with Italy bad been successful. Signor Tittoni and he were working in complete harmony in the direction of ensuring greater cordiality. Though the antagonistic feelings formerly fostered by hostile parties in Italy had not disappeared, they had diminished and a calmer tone was observable in the press. He deplored the extension of the war of extermination among the Christians in Macedonia and commented on the failure of the Turkish authorities to protect them against terrorist bands.

He hoped shortly to effect a junction of the Austrian, Turkish, and Greek railways at La rissa, thus establishing through communication with Athens and providing the shortest route from Central Europe to Egypt and India

div.head: HOTEL CENTRAL BAGNI,SALSOMAGGIORE
div.p: A correspondent of "The Egyptian Gazette" who recently visited Salsomaggiore had the privilege of being shown over the magnificent now thermal baths attached to the Hotel Central Bagni. The great advantage offered by the hotel proprietors to invalids taking the health cure is that the hotel baths are connected with the establishment by a covered bridge, thus enabling them to pass from their rooms to the bath without incurring the risk of exposure to sudden changes of temperature. Especial care and attention is given to ladies travelling alone.
Our correspondent, who has made close personal enquiries, learns that the volume of sufferers from gout, rheumatism, throat and other diseases visiting Salsomaggiore is increasing every year.

div.head: EGYPT'S VISITORS.
div.p: MR. HALL CAINE
A London contemporar; in announcing the departure of Mr. Hall Caine for Egypt says : -
The principal object of his visit is to gather further material for A new novel and a new play.

"To help me to write a novel and a play which I have been trying to work upon for some time," be said, "I am going back to Egypt for a little more study of that fascinating and inexhaustible country, which is, I think, at this moment more important to the nations in general and to England in particular than any other part of the world."
Mr. Caine, who visited Egypt last year, will be away three or four months, dividing his time between Cairo, the centre of Lord Cromer's administration, and Khartoum, the scene of Gordon's martyrdom."

The above is not quite exact. Mr. Hall Caine left Cairo yesterday for Khartoum where he expects to stay about a week. He will probably be back in Cairo in three weeks and stay on another two or three weeks in Cairo. His new book and play will be of startling interest to Egypt and the most earnest and dramatic of all Hall Caine's works. He has made a most profound study of his subject.
EARL AND COUNTESS OF SEFTON.

While the daily papers at home are still reporting that the Earl and Countess of Sefton are leaving England "very shortly" for Egypt, they are in reality well on their way up the Blue Nile, en route for Abyssinia, having spent Christmas at the Palace, Khartoum, as the guests of the Sirdar and Lady Wingate. The object of their expedition to the land of the Negus is sport, and they are accompanied by a well known Highland sportsman, Major the Hop. Hugh Fraser of Lovat. Major Fraser, who is in the Scots Guards, has for several years been seconded as adjutant of the Lovat Sconts, com nanded by his brother but he has now vacated that appointment, and has since been doing duty with his regiment at Aldershot.

Lord Sefton himself, who will be seven and thirty next month, was formerly in the 2nd Lite Guards, and a keen soldier, but retired from the Service in order to look after the family estates when his elder brother was invalided for life by a terrible accident in the hunting-tield. He has the love of sport, which is characteristic of the Molyneuxes, and the present Prime Minister appointed him Master of the Horse when he came into office, but political differences with the Government obliged him to resign the office last year. When at home at Croxteth Park, his big ugly house in South Lancashire, he hunts regularly with the Cheshire packs. His friends know him as "Obby," an inharmonious abbreviation of his pretty Christian name of Osbert. Lady Setton was Lady Helena Bridgeman, third of the four daughters of the Earl and Countess of Brad tord.
SIR J. WEST RIDGEWAY

Fir (Joseph West Ridgeway P.C, GCMG. K.C.B., KCSI, etc. etc., who is staying with Lady Ridgeway at Ghezireh Palace, has had innumerable honours showered upon him at various times during his long and distinguished career. Born in 1844, he entered the Indian Army seventeen years later: he served in the Afghan war of 1879, and was under secretary to the Government of India in the Foreign Department between the years 1880-84. The following year he was appointed Commissioner on the frontier question between Russia and Afghanistan ; in 1886 he was sent on special duty to St. Petersburg. For his services on the Afghan frontier commission he received the thanks of the Viceroy and the English Government, and in consideration of his distinguished services he was promoted Colonel in 1887. That same year he was appointed under secretary for Ireland. In 1892 he was sent as Envoy Extraordinary to the Sultan of Morocco : on his return he became Governor to the Isle of Man. From 1895-1903 he was Governor of Ceylon, and in 1906 he acted as chairman of the committee on the Constitution of the Transvaal and Orange River Colonies.
He was appointed K.S.C.I. in 1885; C.B. civil) in 1887, Privy Conseillor (Ireland) 1889, K C.B. (civil) in 1891, G.CMG, in 1900, and iG.C.B. in 1906.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: we do not bold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary Iimit free discussion
To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,--On Sunday afternoon I had the unique experience of watching the total destruction of & sailing vessel from the windows of the Windsor Hotel. About midday the vessel was sighted first making for the Eastern Harbour, apparently without control owing to the tremendous force of the burriacpe blowing. The flag of distress was then flying from the ship. The Captain, finding himself in a most dan gerous position, dropped his anchor to prevent running ashore. The cable, however, parted almost immediately afterwards. Apparently on recognising that position was hopeless, the boat was lowered and the vessel was left to her tate. The onlookers, who had gathered on the quay to witness the tragic spectacle, had their interest transferred to the ill-fated crew. The little boat seemed to have small chance of reaching a landing place. Exposed to the fall fory of the awful gale, buffeted and harled hither and thither by the gigantic waves, she was ever and again quite lost to sight amidst the mountainous seas.

It was impossible to conceive a more barrow ing spectacle, especially as we were all conscious of our utter helplessness to render any assistance. However, fortune favours the brave fellows, who were at last landed safe and sound on shore, but in a very exhausted state I have no need to enter into any further details of this incident, but what I want to refer to is the complete lack of any lite boat service in Alex andria, although it is the Mediterranean port, which ranks after Marseilles and Genoa. For hours the ship, which eventually dashed itself to pieces against the rocks of the headland of Fort Silsileh, had hoisted the flag of distress. Yet nothing was done by the Ports and Lights Administration nor by the Coastguards Service to render the slightest assistance. In my humble opinion had a powerful tug come to her aid, even an hour and a half after the first signal of distress was hoisted, she might have been easily saved Doubtless the Ports and Lights Administration is too much occupied with her internal scandals to care about the lives of a few seamen, but when I consider that the Director Generalship of that Administration has been in the hands of an Englishman for many years past, I am almost ashamed to disclose my nationality by signing myself.
AN INDIGNANT BRITISHER. Windsor Hotel,

div.byline: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "BOYPTIAN GAZETTE."
div.p: Sir. - I don't know who is responsible for the disgraceful neglect of not providing a lite-boat for the port of this city ; perhaps we all are, more or less "Jack" is certainly not without many friends in Alexandria, as is evidenced by the fact that, on certain occasions, be is regaled with tea, buns, cakes and the sympathetic smiles of his many lady friends. This is all very well, but, can't we do something more for him

This question leads me to suggest that the fund, which have been inscribed for the purpose of a memorial to Lord Croner might be well applied to the purchasing and endow. ing of a lifeboat. I am sure that, if Lord Cromer were consulted, he would approve of the money being so applied. In all sincerity, who really cares one straw about a Khartoum scholarship. Lord Cromer was essentially cosmopolitan : we are all foreigners, in a sense, though we are deeply attached to the country of our adoption, let us, then, band together, under Lord Cromer's flag. and do something really effective and necessary to help the brave seamen of all nations to whom we owe so much, Once started, the scheme would meet with the support of the unfailing generosity of our fellow citizens.
Yours truly,
HUMANITAS

div.byline: THE NEW PASS TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
div.p: Sir,--Having just read in the "Phare d'Alexandrie" or to day the column of shocking abuse of me and my creators based on the misconception that the "Cleopatra" in leaving the Port on Saturday struck on a rock within my limits, I must beg you to allow me to reassure my patrons and clients as to the secure passage through me they have been guaranteed.

No, Sir, I am really a pags and not an impasse as the "Phare" would have you and the | public believe. The "Cleopatra" neither could nor did touch bottom in any portion of me, and the full depth of 35 feet at low water will still be found throughout my limits as promised to you and to be "Phare d'Alexandrie when you did me the honour to celebrate my inauguration on the 30th ult. and drink to my future utility

The cause of the "Cleopatra” striking a rock outside my limits is, no doubt, capable of explanation to the satisfaction of yourself and the Phare d'Alexandrie" by those who were in charge of her navigation on Saturday. Allow me to remain, Sir, your innocent, but much abused
Nouvelle PASSE

div.byline: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT AND THE "EGYPTIAN STANDARD."
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.”
Dear Sir,- In the last three numbers of the Egyptian Standard" I published a series of articles, three in number, I believe, on the Oasis
of Al-Kharged, and in which I dealt likewise of the prospects attending the Corporation of Western Egypt's endeavour reclaim to fertile land from the vast covering of ever-shifting
Band
These articles were to be five in number and consequently I had planned out my work in accordance with the requirements of the case.

Yesterday, to my surprise, I received the visit of Osman Sabry Effendi, the "Responsible Secretary" of the "Egyptian Standard," who politely informed me not to continue my series as the Director of the paper did not wish to advertise the Corporation ! I leave it to the judgment of any reader of my articles to decide whether the accusation is true. What be, the reader, will have discovered, is an unprecedented display of misprints and such alterations as "eity rage" for "city rags," "black cartridges" for "blank cartridges" and other incomprehensible concoctions of a like nature, for the drawing up of which I am at a loss to determine the responsible person or persons.

My object in sending you this letter for publication is simply to justify the apparently unfinished or incomplete nature of my observations in the basis. Strictly speaking, both as regards politeness and justice, the editor of the "Egyptian Standard" ought to have announced the interruption of the articles and have alleged some real or fictitious reasons. I doubt very much whether this has been done.

In conclusion, I may state that personally I think the leader of the National Party is making a big mistake in not favouring the opening up of the oasis. From what I have seen and have been able to judge by myself there is a future in store for these fertile desert valleys. Unfortunately, however, the leader of the National Party gives a rap for the social and economic progress of his country as long as they are not in agreement with his own politics. al ideals Neither Egyptians nor Frenchmen started the idea of opening up the Libyan Oases, and that is why it must be combatted even if proving beneficial to Egypt

Of course, this statement only holds good in case the instructions remitted to me by the responsible secretary really emanated from Mustapha Kanel Pasha, which is very doubtful. It is so easy to make a gick man responsible for the doings of his entourage. I am, Sir, sincerely yours,
CHARLES Rudy

div.byline: THE PARTY OF THE PEOPLE To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
div.p: Sir. A correspondent in to day's issue of the "Gazette" declares that "Lord Cromer departed from Egypt about the middle of April last, and the Party was only proclaimed late in September ; 80 there is no truth in your insinuation in its worst sense) that "ay soon as Lord Cromer departed this "Party of the People" entirely changed its program me. The Party has got only one programme which was announced on the 1st of September last, and since then no modifications have been therein introduced."
The complete inaccuracy of this criticism of your paragraph is evident from Lord Cromer's appreciation of the original aims of this Party contained in the following passage in his last Report :--

"Petore leaving the question of the Egyptian National movement, I have yet one further remark to make. Besides those who have assumed the title of Nationalist, there exists a girl but increasing number of Egyptians of whom comparatively little is heard, but who deserve that title quite as much as their competitors of a different school of thought and action. I allude to the party which, for the sake of brevity, I may call the followers of the late Mufti, Sheikh Mohamed Abdou. I have in previous Reports frequently alluded to the opinions held by this section of Egyptian society-opinions which are very analogous to those advocated by the late Seyyid Ahmed, who founded the Aligarh College in India. Their fundamental idea is to reform various Moslem institutions withoat shaking the main pillars on which the faith of Islam rests. They are truly Nationalist in the sense of wishing to advance the interests of their countrymen and coreligionists, but they are not tainted with Pan-Islamism. Their programme, if I understand it rightly, involves not opposition to, but co-operation with Europeans in the introduction of Western civilization into the country. The main hope of Bgyptian Nationalism, in the only true and practicable sense of the word, lios, in my opinion, with those who belong to this party. In the past they have not, for reasons on which I need not dwell, but for which the British advisers of the Egyptian Government are in no way responsible, received all the encouragement they deserve."

To declare that the party was only constituted last September and that only from that date did it have a programme is nonsense, as everybody knows that the Party came into being through the late Sheikh Abdou and the official organ of the Party, "Al Garidah,” was started before Lord Cromer left and took lig policy at the beginning under inspiration from the British Agency
Truly Yours,
ONLOOKER Cairo,

div.head: PORT SUDAN NOTES.
div.p: THE BAIRAM HOLIDAYS.
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT)

Port SUDAN, January 22 This week has been quite an eventful one; the French cruiser "Surprise" arrived from Suez The Commander made a tour of inspection round the Port and the vessel sailed the following morning at daylight for Masowa,

During the Bairam Holidays, the Atbara team, headed by Bimb. Newoorbe, came down to Port Sudan to play the Sports Club at cricket. At the end of the first day, the scores stood in favour of Port Sudan. There were & great many people present and quite a number of ladies, the latter being passengers of the 83. "Langdale". In the evening & smoking concert was given on behalf of the Atbara teain, which was held in the band room of the new barracks and passed off with great success. Kaim Drury Bey who took the chair made a short speech, to which Bimbashi Newcombe replied on behalf of his team. Quite a number of people volunteered to do something : amongst the items on the programme were a banjo and guitar duet by Messrs Cole and Watkins, comic songs by Mr Pool, who also gave a most amusing turn as a champion heavy weight lifter. He was introduced to the audience under some foreign Dame, and being disguised in his stage attire nobody recognised bim The usual tale was told about him appear. ing before Kings and Princes, etc Not only did he go in for heavy weight lifting, but feats of strength in the shape of tearing two packs of cards, breaking chains with the muscle of his arın, etc., After lifting 750 lbs above his head, he asked any member of the audience to come up aod challenge him. Kanakam Drury Bey was not backward, and immediately proceeded to the stage and after many desperate struggles gave it up. Another gentleman proceeded to test his strength and with great surprise to all present be lifted a pair of dumbells weighing 300 lbs above his head, but in placing same on the ground they broke, much to every one's surprise, and this revealed that they were made of glass and the whole show was a hoax. He then carried the remainder of the heavy weights to be the total of about 2 tons of the stage.
Resuming the cricket match the next day, there was some very smart playing on the part of Port Sudan, and the game finished up as p.m. with a tie.

The launch "Clysma" was very kindly placed ai the teams disposal by Kaimakam Drury Bey and an interesting trip up and down the harbour was enjoyed during the cool of the evening. The team proceeded later to their train at the station and received a cheery send off

Reports are just to hand of a serious accident caused by heavy seas outside Suakin harbour The Sudan Government tug "Hawk", with Capt P. V. Draper at command, was towing abreast a lighter laden with coal to Port Sudan Having encountered some very heavy seas, be decided to put back into port and it was at this moment that three heavy seas were shipped, causing the lighter to become full of water and it sank in less than half a minute, with one hand, a native, on board, whose body has not yet been recovered Capt. Draper grasping the situation, gave orders for the ropes to be cut away, and by doing this was just able to save the "Hawk" from the same fate
A horse owned by the Chief of Police, was

found yesterday morning lying in a pool of blood, and it was afterwards discovered that the animal had been stabbed with a large knife, found, some 80 yeards away. The assaliant has not been found but it is belived to be the work of an Egyptian Policemnan, who may have had some grievance againt his cheif.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier DE “L’EGYPTIAN GAZETTE”
div.p: Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l’ "Egyptian Gazette” parait chaque Samedi à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les der- nières statistiques jusqu’à la veille de sa publi- cation : des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc. L’abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste ; pour l’étranger 10 P.T. de port en sas. Pour de plus amples informations, s’adresser an directeur de l’ "Egyptian Gazette”.

div.head: LARGE UNITS SHIELDS.
div.p: KINGS OWN SCOTTISH BORDERERS
V. KINGS ROYAL RIFLES. K.O.S.B. - Douglas ; Pearce, Welsh, Lieut Craig, Hooper, Priestly; Jones, Dawson, Ingles, Miller
K.RR.C. ---Grimes, Grover, Clark; Conson, Burke, Merill, Blacktin, Peun; Flemming, Holden, Ketterick
Referee Sgt. Richardson, Coldstream Guards.

Quite a large and distinguished gathering witnessed the replay between the above teams at Ghezireh, last Saturday, amongst whom we noticed, Major General Bollock, The Hon. Mr. and Mrs. Iddings and Colonel Markham.

There would be 1200 spectators present when the Borderers kicked off against a strong gusty wind. Play immediately became fast, each end being visited in turn. From the loose the Rifies took the aggressive and Blacktin run. ing down the wing centered to Flemming who netted the initial goal after 10 minutes of the start. Assisted by the wind the Rifles were able to keep the Borderers on the defensive and Flemming added a second goal ten minutes later

Play, became of a give and take nature, and on two occasions it was only the excellent defence of the Rifles custodian that averted disaster. The wind had somewhat abated when the second half was commenced and the Borderers played a splendid upbill game and assisted by the wind gave the Rifles plenty of work. Indeed they had the best of the second half and were unlucky not to have soared thrice in the early stages. From a melee in front of goal, Ingles secured and with a swift low sbot, scored the first goal

Continuing the pressure, Priestly sent in several shots which Grimes did well to save. Shortly before time Lee sent in a shot which struck the crossbar and rebounding to Miller that player netted the equalizer
An extra half hour was resorted to, but neither side scored.

Although the game ended in a draw, the Borderers were far superior to their opponents and should have won by at least three goals. Jones, Priestly and Ingles played a hard sound game and it was only the splendid display of Grimes which saved the situation. He is the finest goalkeeper we have seen for some time. Pean is the only man of the Rifles front division who played with prominence.

"HANDS SWOLLEN TO THE SIZE OF BOXING GLOVES"
TERRIBLY SWOLLEN WITH DROPSY.
CREW HY DOAN BACKACHE KIDNEY Pills.

Over four years after bis cure, Mr. Geo. E Chapwan, 12, Chamberlain Road, West Ealing, London, W., said :-"It is just upon five years since I began to suffer with the dropay and kidney disease of which Doan's Backache Kidney Pills cured me, and when I say cured me I mean it, as my health has been as well as I could wish ever since-no sign whatever of the illness, although I have been driving about in all weathers.

"I well remember how the trouble started - it was with pain right across the back, and it grew so bad that once I was down I could hardly get up again. Later I noticed swellings in my ankles, which spread up my loge 90 rapidly that I had to cease work and take to bed. The swellings quickly came up into my body. arms, hands, and face-my hands were more like boxing-gloves than anything else. In short, I was terribly swollen all over, and must have been an enormous weight. I was quite twice the size that I am now, and everyone who saw me thought I could not possibly get over it. I, too, thought the dropsy would be the end of me, for I felt fit to burst.

"I read of what Doan's Backache Kidney Pills had done in aes of dropay and kidney disease, and then made up my mind to give them a good trial. It was nothing short of marvellous what the pills did. It did not surprise me that the progress was slow-knowing the seriousness of my illness- but it was very sure. I could feel the swellings gradually going down. I stuck to Doan's Backache Kidney Pills right through, and they absolutely cured me. I doubt whether I should have been alive now had it not been for them
"I am as right and fit now as anyone couid wish to be, thanks to Doan's Pills. (Signed),
GEORGE EDWARD CHAPMAN."

And again four and half years after his Irura-Mr. Chapman said to a representative: "I am glad to see you, and more glad to say I am still the same as ever-first-rate I look upon myself as cured for all time."

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Mardi, 28 Janvier Comme hier, il n'y a presque pas eu d'affaires ce matin, et c'est plutot la faiblesse qui a pré. dominé. Cette allure peu satisfaisante est at tribuéo au calme régnant au Stock Exchange dont les ordres d'achat en valeurs égyptiennes ont cessé. De plus, la ligne téléphonique du Caire n'étant pas encore réparée, ce contre temps & contribué pour sa part au ralentissement des arbitrages. Mais ce ne sont là sans doute que des circonstances aggravantes de La situation ; la cause principale de l'inertie semble résider dans le tait que les positions surchargées n'ont pas encore pu s'alléger et tant qu'une partie des paquets n'aura pas changé de mains, comme nous l'avons déjà dit, il y a toujours lieu de redouter une réaction au moindre événement détavorable. Le marche des cotons, qui est également faible, & contribué a la mauvaise humeur dans la corbeille des titres.

C'est au milieu de ce désarroi que la spécu. lation s'est emparée de la Delta Land pour la pousser de 1 5/32 à 1 1/4 acheteurs. Cette soudaine rentrée en faveur n'a paralt il, aucun motif. On acbète, voilà tout. La demande provient principalement du Caire.

Il a été fait un peu de Cassa di Sconto et d'Agricole. Ce qu'il y a de surprenant pour la Cassa, c'est qu'en dépit du bilan et de tous les bruits favorables mis en circulation, le prix a fléchi de 58 a 56. En ce qui concerne l'Agricole, on a observé de la demande, surtont en clôture qui a eu lieu à 7 27/32, en hausse do 1/16.
La National est loin d'être en aussi bonne tenue. Elle tombe de 21 13 16 a 21 9 16 vendeurs, sur des offres persistantes.
Plus faibles aussi la Delta Light qui recule de 9 21/32 9 5/8, l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier de 299 à 298, et le Crédit Fran00 Egyptien de 4 5/32 à 4 1/8.
En Crown Brewery la dégringolade parait De plus vouloir s'arrêter. C'est encore 3 francs qu'elle perd & 92.
L'Ordinary Khedivial Mail rétrograde de 18/3 à 18, la Building Lands de 1 1/2 à 1 7 16, la Port Said Salt de 10/10} á 10,6, la Levant de 17 32 à 12, et l'U'nited de 1/4 à 7 32.
D'autre part, la Salt and Soda se relève de 14/9 & 15/, les Nungovich Hotels de 18 à 13}, le Banco di Roma de 108 A 1081, et la Zariffa de 2 3/4 A 2 7/8.

Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de change ments a signaler. Quant à la tendance, elle est plutôt faible pour le moment. Mais ce qui paralt extraordinaire en cette saison, qu'on était habitué à voir ai animée, c'est la rareté des transactions

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe.
Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.&O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers “Osiris" and “Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.’s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy’s most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, “Entombment," by Ciseri, and ‘Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D’OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

It is hardly necessary to point out to Tourists the extraordinary interest of a visit to Athens from an artistic, historical and archaelogical point of view, and if possible tourists should average to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara, for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: Navy Contracts.
div.p: Port Said, and Suez
TENDERS are hereby invited for new Contracts for the supply of Fresh Beef, Mutton, Vegetables, Soft Brea!, and Water to His Majesty's Ships at Port Said and Suez for twelve months from 1st April 1908
Each article should be tendered for separately, but the tender for all the articles offered b;' any particular firm must be placed on the game Form

Prices should be quoted in English currency. Forms of Application can be obtained from the Navy Agent, British Consulate General, Port Said, to whom readers should be sent in duplicate, in sealed envelope, in time to be received not later than the 31st January, 1908
The Admiralty reserve the right of rejecting ail or any tenders, and of accepting any portion of tender.
(Signed) D. A. CAMERON,
Navy Agent British Consulate General, Port Said, 10th January, 1908

div.head: Notice to Advertisers.
div.p: The “Egyptian Gazette" has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt any monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are received at the offices of the "Gazette" from advertisers direct.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture de livers articles necessaires à ses ser ces
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE 24
Le cahier des charges est depune su bureau Techuique où il pent être consulte par les intéressés tous les jours de 9h & midi, les jours feries exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sons pli cacheté à Monsieur Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 29 Janvier 1909
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour À 5 h. p. m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la men tion "Soumission pour fourniture divers articles."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banqne, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 28 janvier 1908 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée. Alexandrie, le 20 Janvier 1908.
L'Administrateur 31803 3:
(Signe) W.P. CHATAWAI.

div.head: Coleman's WINCARNIS
div.p: THE WORLDS' GREATEST RESTORATIVE.

Coleman's Wincarnis should be taken in every case where strength is needed. To the whole this splendid tonic wine means prolongation of life; the convalescent, quick recovery; to the ana mic, new blood; and to all who are "rundown," the speedy regaining of metal and bodily fitness.
Wincarnis Creates Energy and Stamina.

Whenever there is prolonged strain, either mental or physical, and especially when too great a totx is being placed on the nervous system, Wincarnis is essential for preventing the breakdown in health which tends to follow over-exertion. Wincarnis makes the weak strong, but it is just as necessary for retaining the health of the robust when there are thekening influences at work.
Wincarnis Braces the Nervous System.
